In their statement, there are two acknowledgements of God's power. First, their acknowledgement of the oneness of God in maintaining and creating this universe. Second, their acknowledgement of the oneness of God and His right to be worshipped by creation. The polytheists acknowledged the oneness of God in creating and maintaining this universe, as explained by Allah in His word:

And if you ask them, "Who created the heavens and the earth and subjected the sun and the moon?" They will surely say, "Allah." Then how are they turned away (from the truth)? (al-'Ankabut/29: 61)

Nevertheless, the polytheists did not acknowledge the oneness of God and His right to be worshipped by His servants. They worshipped idols as partners of God who would bring them closer to Him, as explained in the word of Allah SWT:

"...We only worship them so that they may bring us nearer to Allah." (az-Zumar/39: 3)

After the young men declared their acknowledgement of the oneness of God, they then gave the reason for their rejection of the worship of idols as desired by King Decyanus. They stated that if they worshipped and prayed to other than Allah, it would mean doing something far from the truth.
text.15:
In this verse, Allah swt recounts the conversation among the young men. They said that their people, who were under the rule of Decyanus, although older and with much experience, associated partners with God without using their intellect. Why did they not present a valid reason, or strong and clear evidence to strengthen the truth they spoke and believed in? The young men stated that their people should do as they did, which was to show evidence of the truth of the religion they adhered to.

The young men also stated that there is no greater injustice except the injustice of those who fabricate lies against Allah, such as saying that God has partners. Their people had equated the status of idols with the high status of God, but they could not provide a valid reason, even though religion should be based on belief or a valid reason. They fabricated names for the designation of God by only following their desires.

The word of Allah swt:

"They are but names which you have named - you and your forefathers - for which Allah has sent down no authority. They follow not except assumption and what [their] souls desire, and there has already come to them from their Lord guidance." (an-Najm/53: 23)

The names given to the partners of Allah are various, such as al-Lata, al-Manat, al-Uzza, which are names for idols given by the people of Arab Jahiliyah.
text.16:
In this verse, it is explained that the conversation among them continued, some of them said to others, "When you distance yourselves from your people and your homeland, inwardly and outwardly, refusing to follow their customs, and unwilling to worship other than Allah, thus provoking their anger towards you, then you should seek refuge in a place like a cave."

"In that place, you can worship diligently and devoutly and be safe from the disturbance of your people. When you have fully devoted yourselves to Allah, and seek His protection, then He will surely shower His mercy upon you. You will not die of starvation or thirst in that cave. Allah SWT will provide a way out for you in overcoming the difficulties of food and drink or other things. Allah will ease the way for you to worship Him perfectly so that you can feel the pleasure of worship that exceeds all other pleasures." This was the content of their conversation. What they said arose from their belief and hope in Allah's grace and the blessings of their complete surrender and faith in Him. Allah SWT moved the hearts of those young men to become righteous people, inhabitants of the cave. Their story is ultimately always remembered in the history of religious communities. Such was the nature of those young men, their hearts forever purer and more loving of the truth, which is a very good quality needed for a leader.

Ibn 'Abbas said:

لَمْ يَبْعَثِ اللَّهُ نَبِيًّا إِلَّا شَابًّا، وَلَمْ يُؤْتَ الْعَالِمُ عِلْمًا إِلَّا وَهُوَ شَابٌّ

"Allah did not send a prophet except as a young man, and knowledge was not given to a scholar except when he was a young man."

Then he recited the following verses:

Mereka (yang lain) berkata, "Kami mendengar ada seorang pemuda yang mencela (berhala-berhala ini), namanya Ibrahim." (al-Anbiya/21: 60)

"They (the others) said, "We heard a young man mentioning them who is called Abraham." (al-Anbiya/21: 60)

And the word of Allah SWT:

Dan (ingatlah) ketika Musa berkata kepada pembantunya. (al-Kahf/18: 60)

"And (remember) when Moses said to his servant." (al-Kahf/18: 60)

And the word of Allah SWT:

Sesungguhnya mereka adalah pemuda-pemuda yang beriman kepada Tuhan mereka, dan Kami tambahkan petunjuk kepada mereka. (al-Kahf/18: 13)

"Indeed, they were youths who believed in their Lord, and We increased them in guidance." (al-Kahf/18: 13)

This verse shows the steadfastness of the Ashhabul Kahf youths when they secluded themselves in the cave because they were hiding their religion. Al-Ghazali, in his book Ihya' 'Ulumuddin, rejects using this verse as evidence for the virtue of living in seclusion (uzlah). He said, "The Ashhabul Kahf did not isolate themselves from one another. They were all believers. They isolated themselves from the disbelievers." So it was natural for them to practice *uzlah* in order to be protected from the torture of the disbelievers and the king who wanted to kill them. Living in seclusion in the sense of isolating oneself from evil and falsehood that cannot be corrected or that they are unable to correct, then this kind of *uzlah* is justified. As-Suyuti in his book Al-Iklil argues that from this verse it can be understood that *uzlah*, isolating oneself, fleeing from injustice, and staying in a cave are prescribed when the religious situation is not conducive or is corrupt. His opinion needs clarification because it is still vague. What era is free from corruption? What can actually be understood from this verse is that the young men isolated themselves because there was a violation of the right to live religiously.

Living in *uzlah* because of frustration and despair in facing the reality of life is not justified by religion. To understand this verse, attention must be paid to the atmosphere at the time of the youths' *uzlah* event. They secluded themselves by fleeing into the cave because they were about to be killed by an arbitrary king. The situation at that time also did not support fighting against the king's arbitrariness and showing their faith.

In the early days of Islam, the Prophet ordered his companions to migrate to Abyssinia, then to Medina, and he himself then also migrated there because of the ferocity of the Quraysh polytheists, while the Muslims could do nothing to face them, because they were still weak. In fact, for the Prophet SAW in particular, they were preparing to kill him. They surrounded the Prophet's house at night to carry out the assassination plan.

Because the polytheists had conspired to kill the Prophet, Allah commanded the Prophet to migrate. It was on the basis of that command that the Prophet migrated. So, it was not because of fleeing from the battlefield, being alone or *uzlah*, and so on. Living *uzlah* in the sense of isolating oneself from the luxury of life and the enslavement of wealth and desires, then living simply in the midst of society, as shown by the Prophet's companion Abu Dharr al-Ghifari, is not blameworthy, but is even justified by Islam. Ibn Kathir said, "Abu Dharr believed that it was not appropriate for a Muslim to have wealth exceeding the provision of his food for a day and a night, or something he used for fighting, or something provided for guests. He adhered to the *dhahir* of the verse:

Dan orang-orang yang menyimpan emas dan perak dan tidak menginfakkannya di jalan Allah, maka berikanlah kabar gembira kepada mereka, (bahwa mereka akan mendapat) azab yang pedih. (at-Taubah/9: 34)

"And those who hoard gold and silver and do not spend it in the way of Allah - give them tidings of a painful punishment." (at-Taubah/9: 34)

Abu Dharr lived in simplicity because he did not want to be involved in the luxurious life that began to spread during the time of Caliph Uthman RA. This is an example of the life of *uzlah* found among the companions of the Messenger of Allah SAW."
text.17:
After the young men discussed their people and themselves, they decided to retreat (uzlah) to a cave on a mountain they agreed upon. In this verse, Allah explains the condition of their shelter. The cave's entrance faced north. In the morning, the sun rose from the east, and in the afternoon, the sun inclined to the west, crossing the cave's entrance. Thus, sunlight only directly touched the cave's entrance from the left and right sides. The cave's inhabitants themselves were not exposed to sunlight, even though they were in a spacious place. The cave's interior received sunlight that refracted from the cave's mouth. Therefore, the room was not dark and always had cool air. Regarding the location of this cave, the commentators (ahli tafsir) have different opinions. Some say that the cave was in an area near Aela (Jerusalem) in Palestine. Ibn Ishaq said it was in Nainawa, an old city in the Mousul area. Others say it was in the Roman lands. The above information states that these stories took place in the city of Ephesus, based on accounts from the Arabs. However, until now, there is no strong evidence of where the cave actually is. If it were beneficial, the Messenger of Allah (saw) would have told us where it was.

These are the signs of Allah's power shown to His believing servants. All the events experienced by the young men, from the time they received guidance to the path of monotheism (tauhid), their hostility with their people and families without regard for personal interests, even though they were young, then their accurate choice of a healthy cave as a dwelling place, and then their awakening after being asleep in the cave for more than 300 years, show signs of Allah's power found in this universe. But all these signs can only be appreciated by those who are given taufik by Allah swt to receive guidance to the path of truth, like the young men of the cave. They are the ones who obtained guidance and accurately chose the path of truth, so they are happy in worldly and otherworldly life (duniawi and ukhrawi). They have achieved and experienced all the blessings and help of Allah swt that they had always hoped for.

In contrast to them are those who do not receive guidance. These are the people who are misguided because they choose the wrong path to take. Inclination towards worldly desires causes them to choose the wrong path of truth. They fall into the error of a path that does not bring happiness. Allah misguides them because that is indeed their condition. It is very difficult for them to find a guide who will return them to the straight path and release them from error, because faith and disbelief lie in the will of Allah. He gives taufik to His servants whom He wills and leaves those whom He wills in error.
text.18:
After finding a safe place in the cave, they devoted themselves to worship within it until God sealed their hearing, causing them to fall asleep. In this verse, Allah swt explains their state while sleeping. They appeared to be awake, but were actually asleep. Ibn Kathir said, "Some scholars explain that when Allah sealed their hearing by putting them to sleep, their eyes did not close completely so that air could still enter. Because their eyes were open, they were thought to be awake; as if they were seeing whoever stood before them. In reality, they were truly asleep, but unlike ordinary human sleep. Generally, during ordinary sleep, there are signs of rest from the body's organs, especially in the eyes and face. The sleep of the cave dwellers deviated from the *sunnatullah* that applies, because the Creator of the Universe willed to show His power and sovereignty over the universe to disbelieving humans.

Even in their sleep, Allah moved them, turning them to the left and to the right, as is common for living people who are sleeping. However, this does not diminish the extraordinary nature of the sleep itself. Their turning cannot be equated with the turning of someone in ordinary sleep to keep the body maintained. Allah is All-Powerful to maintain their bodies, even if they did not turn to the left and to the right. Allah moved them at certain times to show the existence of life and to distinguish them from statues or mummies, which are inanimate objects. Even if, for example, they turned to the left and to the right once a year, it would be enough to show an extraordinary miracle to those who witnessed it because they slept for more than three hundred years.

The opinions of the *mufassirun* vary in this matter. Some say they turned every six months, some say once a year on the day of *Asyura*, some say every nine years, and so on. The calculation of time is not important to know. Their pet dog was lying down with its two front legs near the cave entrance. The atmosphere in the cave was very eerie. Anyone who wanted to enter to see their condition would certainly feel afraid and run away. No one dared to enter the cave. God created an eerie and frightening atmosphere in the cave, according to Ibn Kathir, so that no one would approach and touch them until the appointed time determined by Allah swt came. Because this event contains great wisdom, and a strong reason that Allah's promise is true and the Day of Judgment is certain to come.
text.19:
In this verse, Allah swt explains about the young men of Ashhabul Kahf when they awoke from their sleep. Their condition, including their bodies, skin, hair, and everything else, was the same as before they slept. They were all healthy and intact, even the clothes they wore remained intact. Allah swt showed them His majesty, greatness, and power, as well as the wonders and extraordinary nature of His actions towards His creation. Therefore, their faith grew stronger to free themselves from the worship of idols, and their hearts became more sincere in worshipping only Allah, the One and Only.

After waking up from their long sleep, they asked each other to find out their situation. One of them said to his companions, "How long have you stayed in this cave?" He expressed his ignorance about his own condition during sleep, then asked the others to provide information. His companions replied, "We have stayed in this cave for a day or half a day." Even those who answered could not be sure how long they had stayed, a day or half a day, because the effects of sleep had not yet disappeared from their minds. They had not seen any signs indicating how long they had been in the cave. Most commentators say that they entered the cave in the morning, and then the Lord woke them up from their sleep in the afternoon. That is why the person who answered thought that they had been in the cave for one or half a day. Then his other companions said, "Your Lord knows best how long you have stayed here." The statement of this last young man was very wise in refuting the statements and answers of his previous companions. The statement seemed to be inspired by Allah swt, or based on real evidence. Indeed, that long period can only be known and determined with certainty by Allah swt. They finally realized the limitations of their ability to know the unseen.

After realizing this, their attention turned to their basic needs, namely food and drink. One of them was ordered to go to the city with silver coins to buy food. According to the narration, his name was Tamlikha. Before buying, he was first asked to pay attention to the food, which was halal and which was haram, and which was good and which was less good. The halal and good food was what he brought back to their shelter. Tamlikha was asked to be careful on the journey, both when entering the city and returning from the city, so that he would not tell anyone about their situation and hiding place.

From the verse fragment "fab'atsu ahadakum biwariqikum hadzih(i)", which means "(then send) one of you to the city with this silver coin of yours", there is an *istimbat* (derivation) of a law related to *wakalah* (representation). Namely, a person is allowed to entrust to another person, as his replacement, matters of property and rights during his lifetime. Ibn al-'Arabi argues that this verse is the strongest basis for *wakalah* (representation).
text.20: Then the cave dwellers warned Tamlikha that if the city's inhabitants, whom they assumed were still disbelievers, found out about their hiding place, they would certainly be forced to follow the idolatrous religion. If they refused, they would certainly be killed by stoning, a method of execution in ancient times for those who dared to oppose the king's political policies or the state religion. The city they were about to reach was Ephesus, and they presumed its king was still the tyrannical Decyanus. In fact, that king was long gone, as he had ruled three centuries ago. If they were forced to return to embracing the religion of Decyanus, they would not obtain happiness and good fortune forever, neither in worldly life nor in the hereafter. The soul of a person who adheres to a religion because they are forced, initially, will reject all the stipulations of that religion. However, over time, it is very likely that their soul will no longer reject it and will eventually view their new religion favorably. If this happens, they will be misguided and miserable forever. However, if someone is forced with threats to convert to disbelief, and they outwardly show disbelief, but their inner self remains Muslim, and until the end of their life they never view the forced religion favorably, then they remain in Islam.
text.21:
In this verse, their subsequent situation is explained. After Tamlikha went to the city to shop, carrying silver coins from his companions, he saw that the atmosphere of the city of Ephesus was very different from what he had expected. When he arrived in the city, he found that its people already believed in the One God. However, among the people, some fully believed in the occurrence of the Day of Judgment, while others still doubted. Some said that the resurrection would be with the soul only, while others said that the resurrection would be with both soul and body.

Just as Allah awakened Ashhabul Kahf from their sleep, so that they could ask each other about themselves, so that their faith would become more perfect, so too did God bring the people of the city together with Ashhabul Kahf, when they were in disagreement about the issue of the Day of Judgment. With the event of Ashhabul Kahf, their disagreements would disappear and their faith in God's power would become perfect. They were convinced that the Day of Judgment would truly occur and that humans would be resurrected from the grave with their bodies and souls, just like the resurrection of Ashhabul Kahf.

According to Israiliyat narrations, the beginning of their meeting with Tamlikha occurred when he took out his silver coin to pay for the food he bought. The silver coin had a picture of King Decyanus on it. The food seller was surprised and shocked. He then took the coin to the city officials, and Tamlikha was questioned and examined. The end of the examination was Tamlikha's confession of who he was and his indication of the cave where they were hiding. This event caused an uproar in the community. The people and the king witnessed an extraordinary event that led them to believe in the occurrence of the Day of Resurrection. The group that had previously doubted the Day of Judgment, with their testimony to this event, changed to believing with perfect faith that Allah SWT is able to revive the dead and restore their bodies to their original form when the soul left the body. So in this verse, Allah SWT states that the meeting of Ashhabul Kahf with the people of the city of Ephesus was so that they would know with certainty that Allah's promise is true and the coming of the Day of Judgment (the Day of Resurrection) is beyond doubt.

After the meeting between the king and community leaders with Ashhabul Kahf ended, Ashhabul Kahf returned to their resting place. At that time, Allah SWT took their souls to be raised to His side. Then the king and the community leaders held a deliberation. Some of them said to the others, "Erect a large building as a memorial near the mouth of the cave." The one in authority among them said, "We will surely build a place of worship near the mouth of their cave." Both sides wanted to honor Ashhabul Kahf, but they disagreed on how. One side wanted to erect a large building, while the other wanted to build a mosque as a place of worship for them. Whether the people of Ephesus built a building for remembrance or they built a mosque for a place of worship above the cave, only Allah knows.

Building a mosque near a grave is not prohibited by religion. But religion strongly forbids making graves a place of worship, as the Prophet Muhammad SAW said:

"Allah curses the Jews and Christians who made the graves of their prophets places of worship." (Narrated by al-Bukhari from 'Aisha and 'Abdullah bin 'Abbas)

Islam strongly forbids its followers from making graves a place of worship to honor those who are buried there. In fact, some scholars, such as Ibn Hajar in his book az-Zawajir, consider this act to be a major sin, based on the hadith mentioned. History has proven that the graves of prophets or saints that are built in places of worship tend to lead people to excessive reverence for the grave. This opens the opportunity for shirk to occur.
text.22:
In this verse, Allah swt explains the disagreements that occurred during the time of the Prophet Muhammad saw regarding this story. The Christians of the Malkaniyah sect said, "They were three in number, the fourth being their dog." The Christians of the Ya'qubiyah sect argued, "They were five in number, and the sixth was their dog." Meanwhile, the Nestorian group said, "They were seven in number, and the eighth was their dog." In this regard, Allah states that their saying three or five people is merely speculation, and not accompanied by knowledge, like throwing a stone at night at a target that is not visible to the eye. But Allah did not state that the person who said seven people was a vague estimate. Therefore, according to Ibn 'Abbas, the opinion that says their number was seven and the eighth was their dog is the correct one. Because Allah swt stated that the two previous opinions were uncertain estimates, but did not say the same for the third opinion. This indicates that the third statement is the correct one and also shows that the statement is based on knowledge, conviction, and inner certainty.

Regarding the names of the seven, which have various pronunciations, according to al-hafidh Ibn Hajar in the Kitab Tarikh by Bukhari, none can be used as a reference, because they are not Arabic names. In Tafsir Ibn Kathir, their names are mentioned as follows: Maksalmina (the oldest), Tamlikha (the second), Marthunus, Birunus, Dominus, Yathbunus, Falyastathyunus, and the name of the dog is Hamran or Qitmir. These names are taken from the People of the Book, so their truth is still doubtful. Only Allah knows best.

Then Allah swt commanded His Messenger to state to those who disagreed about the number of the young men of the cave that Allah swt knows their number better. There is no need to discuss such things without knowledge, it is better to leave it to Allah. If Allah had informed His Messenger about it, of course he would have conveyed it to his people if it was beneficial for their lives in this world and the hereafter. If it is not mentioned, there is no need to waste energy thinking about it.

But then, Allah affirms "no one knows their number except a few." Here Allah indicates that there are a handful of people who are given knowledge by Allah to know the true state of the inhabitants of the cave. Who are those few? Ibn 'Abbas, a young companion in his time and regarded as a scientific figure in all fields, said that he was among those few. Historians, archaeologists, may be included in that small group when their research activities obtain historical facts about past people. However, the most important thing for Muslims from this verse is not to seek information about the number of young men, but how to take lessons and lessons from this event, which are useful for building faith and piety to Allah swt.

After Allah mentions this story, Allah forbids the Prophet two things: First, he must not argue about Ashabul Kahf with the People of the Book. The Prophet is forbidden to argue about this except in a gentle manner, without determining the number of Ashabul Kahf, and not to make them look foolish because it is not useful. The main purpose of this story is to believe that the Day of Resurrection will surely occur.

In another surah with the same intention, Allah says:

And do not argue with the People of the Scripture except in a way that is better, except for those who commit injustice among them. (al-'Ankabut/29: 46)

The second prohibition, Allah swt commanded the Prophet saw not to ask for information about the young men from the Christians because they also have no basis of knowledge about it. They only estimate and without strong evidence.
text.23:
When the polytheists posed three questions to the Prophet Muhammad, peace be upon him, at the suggestion of the Jewish priests in Medina, namely about the Companions of the Cave (Ashhabul Kahf), Dhul Qarnain, and the soul (roh), he said, "Tomorrow morning I will answer what you asked." He did not mention the words *insha Allah* (God willing) in his statement. Before concluding the story of Ashhabul Kahf, in this verse, Allah reminds His Messenger not to make a promise or a statement for a task with certainty by saying, "I will do it tomorrow morning." He should have known that no one knows for sure what will happen tomorrow morning.

Allah's saying:

And no soul knows what it will earn tomorrow. (Luqman/31: 34)

What he promised to the polytheists was only fulfilled fifteen days later, after the revelation to answer those questions was revealed.
text.24:
In this verse, Allah SWT explains that the Prophet's answer to the questions of the polytheists of Mecca should be accompanied by the words "insha Allah," which means "if Allah wills." This is because it is possible that a person will die before the next day comes, and perhaps there will be an obstacle, so that he cannot do what he said. If he accompanies it with the words insha Allah, then he will certainly not be considered a liar in his promise.

If a person forgets to say the words insha Allah in his promise, he should say that sentence when he remembers it at any time. As an example, the Messenger SAW once said the words insha Allah after he remembered. As narrated by Abu Dawud, he said, "By Allah, I will surely fight the Quraysh," then he was silent and said, "Insha Allah..."

Allah SWT then commands His Messenger to earnestly hope to Him that Allah will guide him to a path that is closer to goodness and stronger to be used as a reason for the truth of religion. Allah SWT has fulfilled the hope of the Prophet SAW by revealing the stories of the prophets along with their respective peoples in all ages. From the stories of the prophets and their people, Muslims obtain very beneficial lessons for their lives in this world and the hereafter.
text.25:
Allah then explained how long the Ashhabul Kahf stayed in the cave after their hearing was closed. They slept in the cave for three hundred years according to the calculations of the People of the Book based on solar years (syamsiah), or three hundred years plus nine years according to the calculations of the Arabs based on lunar years (qamariah).

Allah's explanation of how long the Ashhabul Kahf slept in the cave is a miracle for the Prophet Muhammad. He did not study astronomy, but he knew the difference of nine years between the calculation with the solar system over 300 years and the lunar year calculation system. Every hundred solar years, the difference in calculation is three years with the lunar year. Every thirty solar years, the difference in calculation is one year with the lunar year, and every one solar year differs by eleven days with the lunar year.

The knowledge above certainly comes from Allah. Allah also diverts human attention to the beauty found on the surface of the earth, such as the sun, moonlight, and all the beauty created by sunlight. The change of seasons gives birth to various beauties, and the change of seasons itself is caused by changes in the position of the sun. Likewise, plants and animals, which are diverse in their lives, depend on the sunlight that is emitted to the earth. The Prophet Muhammad saw was sent to mankind to explain that studying all the beauty that exists on this earth brings one closer to the truth and oneness of Allah. The creation of the universe is more complex than the creation of man himself. Allah says:

Indeed, the creation of the heavens and the earth is greater than the creation of mankind, but most of mankind do not know. (Gafir/40: 57)
text.26: In this verse, Allah SWT commands the Messenger SAW to declare to those who are still disputing about how long the Ashhabul Kahf slept in the cave, that God knows best how long they slept in that cave. What Allah explains is certainly true, there is no doubt about it. The People of the Book disagreed about the length of time they slept, just as they disagreed about their number. Only Allah knows how long they slept, because He is the All-Knowing and possesses knowledge of all that is unseen, both on earth and in the heavens. He is the All-Knowing of all hidden human affairs, and nothing is hidden from Him. Therefore, people no longer need to discuss how long the inhabitants of the cave slept in their place, but leave it to Allah, because He is the One who knows the unseen, let alone the visible. How clear is Allah's sight over everything that happens in the universe, and how sharp is His hearing of all kinds of sounds and noises from His creatures. There is no one who can be a protector for the inhabitants of the cave other than Allah. He is the One who maintains and manages all their affairs in the best possible way. And He does not associate anyone with Him in making decisions.
text.27:
In this verse, Allah swt commands His Messenger to recite the Qur'an that was revealed to him, to practice its contents, to convey it to mankind, and to follow the commands and prohibitions contained within it. The task of the Messenger saw is to convey Allah's revelation to mankind, as explained in His word:

"O Messenger! Convey [to the people] what has been revealed to you from your Lord. And if you do not, then you have not conveyed His message. And Allah will protect you from the people. Indeed, Allah does not guide the disbelieving people." (al-Ma'idah/5: 67)

The Messenger of Allah does not need to heed the words of those who want the verses of the Qur'an to be brought in accordance with their interests. They say, "Bring a Qur'an other than this or change it." Indeed, no one can replace or change the words of the Qur'an, whether it be words of command or prohibition, whether it be words of threat against those who commit disobedience or Allah's promise to those who are obedient and do good. Only Allah is able to change or replace His words based on His wisdom. Allah swt says:

"Allah eliminates what He wills or confirms, and with Him is the Mother of the Book." (ar-Ra'd/13: 39)

The replacement of verses by Allah in the Qur'an is intended to achieve a purpose that is of greater benefit, as His word says:

"And when We substitute a verse in place of a verse - and Allah is most knowing of what He sends down..." (an-Nahl/16: 101)

All provisions or laws that Allah has established must be obeyed. If not, there will certainly be a punishment given by Allah in accordance with what was previously threatened to those who violate the lines that He has established. No one can be a protector, except Allah swt because His power encompasses His creation. No one can escape the punishment that He has decreed.
text.28:
It is narrated that 'Uyainah bin Hishn al-Fazary came to the Prophet Muhammad saw before he embraced Islam. At that time, some of the Prophet's poor companions were beside him, including Salman al-Farisi, who was wrapped in a robe and his body was sweating because he was weaving palm leaves. 'Uyainah said to the Messenger of Allah, "Doesn't the smell of them (the poor companions) bother you? We are the leaders of the Mudar tribe. If we embrace Islam, then all the Mudar tribe will embrace Islam. Nothing prevents us from following you except their presence. Therefore, keep them away so that we can follow you, or hold a separate assembly for them and a separate assembly for us." Then this verse was revealed. In this verse, Allah swt commands His Messenger to be patient and restrain himself from sitting with some of his companions who are diligent in worship throughout the day, seeking only the pleasure of Allah swt. These companions lived in simplicity, far from worldly pleasures. Among them were: Ammar bin Yasir, Bilal, Shuhaib, Ibn Mas'ud, and other companions. In another surah, Allah says: "And do not drive away those who call upon their Lord morning and afternoon, seeking His pleasure. Not upon you is anything of their account, and not upon them is anything of your account, so you would drive them away and thus be among the wrongdoers." (al-An'am/6: 52) The attitude of the polytheists towards the Prophet's poor companions was similar to the attitude of Noah's people towards the followers of Prophet Noah a.s., as Allah swt says: "They said, "Should we believe you, while you are followed by the lowest [of people]?" (asy-Syu'ara'/26: 111) It was fitting that the Messenger of Allah saw should not heed the attitude of the disbelievers. Allah swt warned him not to abandon or underestimate his poor companions, solely driven by worldly interests or because of the hope for the faith of the rich among the polytheists. These companions were people who sincerely chose a simple way of life and were willing to abandon all worldly pleasures solely to seek the pleasure of Allah. The Messenger of Allah saw gave thanks to Allah for their presence among his people. He said: "All praise is due to Allah who has brought forth among my people those with whom I have been commanded to patiently restrain myself." (Narrated by Ibn Jarir ath-Thabari, Ath-Thabrani, and Ibn Mardawaih) Thus, looking down on and underestimating people who live in poverty and misery is not justified by the Islamic religion, especially if they are people of worship and piety. Allah explicitly forbade Muhammad saw from fulfilling the wishes of the leaders of the polytheists to remove the poor from his assembly. Those who make such requests are people whose souls are closed to returning to God and who have bad character. Their excessive actions, wickedness, and disobedience darken their hearts, so that they eventually wallow in sin.

(29) In this verse, Allah swt commands His Messenger to affirm to the disbelievers that the truth conveyed to them comes from Allah, the Lord of the Universe. Their obligation is to follow that truth and practice it. The benefits of that truth will certainly return to those who practice it. Likewise, the bad consequences of denying the truth will return to those who deny it. Therefore, whoever wants to believe in Him and join the ranks of the believers should do so immediately without making fabricated conditions and excuses, as did the leaders of the polytheists who looked down on the poor believers. The same applies to those who deny and underestimate the truth. The Messenger of Allah saw will not suffer any loss because of that denial, just as he will not gain any benefit if they believe. Allah swt says:

"If you do good, you do good for yourselves; and if you do evil, [you do it] for yourselves." (al-Isra'/17: 7)

But if people choose disbelief and abandon faith, it means they have committed injustice, that is, putting something in the wrong place. Therefore, Allah gives them a severe threat, which is to throw them into hell. They will not escape from that hell, because the blazing fire of hell surrounds them from all sides, so that they are like people trapped in a cage. When they ask each other for a drink in hell because of thirst, they will be given water as hot as molten iron that scalds their faces. How terrible is the water they drink. It is impossible for drinking water that is so hot to refresh the throat and quench the thirst of someone who is hot, but on the contrary, it destroys them. The hell they occupy is the worst place and full of torment.
text.29:
It is narrated that 'Uyainah bin Hishn al-Fazary came to the Prophet Muhammad saw before he embraced Islam. At that time, some of the Prophet's poor companions were beside him, including Salman al-Farisi, who was wrapped in a robe and his body was sweating because he was weaving palm leaves. 'Uyainah said to the Messenger of Allah saw, "Doesn't the smell of them (the poor companions) bother you? We are the leaders of the noble Mudar tribe. If we embrace Islam, then all the Mudar tribe will embrace Islam. Nothing prevents us from following you except their presence. Therefore, keep them away so that we may follow you, or hold a separate assembly for them, and a separate assembly for us." Then this verse was revealed.

In this verse, Allah swt commands His Messenger to be patient and restrain himself from sitting with some of his companions who are diligent in worship throughout the day because they seek only the pleasure of Allah swt. These companions lived in simplicity, far from worldly pleasures. Among them were: Ammar bin Yasir, Bilal, Shuhaib, Ibn Mas'ud, and other companions.

In another surah, Allah says:

And do not drive away those who call upon their Lord in the morning and the evening, desiring His countenance. Not upon you is anything of their account, and not upon them is anything of your account, so you would drive them away and thus be among the wrongdoers. (al-An'am/6: 52)

The attitude of the polytheists towards the Prophet's poor companions was similar to the attitude of Noah's people towards the followers of Prophet Noah a.s., as Allah swt stated:

They said, "Should we believe you, while you are followed by the lowest [of people]?" (asy-Syu'ara'/26: 111)

The Messenger of Allah saw should not have heeded the attitude of those disbelievers. Allah swt warned him not to abandon or underestimate his poor companions, solely driven by worldly interests or because of the hope for the faith of the rich among the polytheists. These companions were people who sincerely chose a simple way of life and were willing to leave behind all worldly pleasures solely to seek the pleasure of Allah. The Messenger of Allah saw gave thanks to Allah for their presence among his people. He said:

All praise is due to Allah who has brought forth among my people those with whom I have been commanded to patiently restrain myself. (Narrated by Ibn Jarir ath-Thabari, Ath-Thabrani, and Ibn Mardawaih)

Thus, looking down on and underestimating people who live in poverty and misery is not justified by the Islamic religion, especially if they are people of worship and piety. Allah explicitly forbade Muhammad saw from complying with the wishes of the leaders of the polytheists to remove the poor from his assembly. Those who make such requests are people whose souls are closed off from returning to God and have bad character. Their excessive actions, wickedness, and disobedience darken their hearts, so that they eventually wallow in sin.
text.30:
In this verse, Allah explains the reward for those who believe in the Qur'an and practice all the commands of Allah and His Messenger in the best possible way, which is that they will be given a great reward. Allah will not waste the reward for the good deeds they do, nor will He reduce their rights in the slightest. There are many promises of Allah in the Qur'an to the believers, including that if they do good deeds, Allah will not waste them in the slightest. Every good deed, even if it is only the size of a mustard seed, will certainly be rewarded by Allah SWT, as His word states:

"So whoever does an atom's weight of good will see it, And whoever does an atom's weight of evil will see it." (al-Zalzalah/99: 7-8)
text.31:
In this verse, Allah SWT elaborates on the reward for those who believe in the Qur'an and perform righteous deeds. Allah SWT provides for them Gardens of 'Adn beneath which rivers flow. The Gardens of 'Adn are so vast that the gardens within them are like paradises in themselves. They are also bestowed with beautiful ornaments, namely gold bracelets that adorn their hands. These glittering ornaments only fill the hands that were once touched by the water of wudu.

The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) said:

"The ornaments of the believers (in Paradise) will fill the places reached by wudu." (Narrated by al-Bukhari and Muslim from Abu Hurairah)

In addition to these ornaments, they will also wear garments of fine and thick green silk, layered with threads of gold. Indeed, these garments are considered very luxurious in worldly life. The color green is a natural color, a color that soothes the eyes and feelings. For their resting place in Paradise, several *arikah* (sofas), a type of seat for reclining while enjoying rest, are provided. Such is Paradise, the best of rewards and a beautiful place, which Allah has prepared for His servants who believe and do righteous deeds.
text.32:
In this verse, Allah presents two men as a parable to explain to the wealthy polytheistic leaders the difference between faith and disbelief, or between a servant who is noble in His sight and one who is despicable. Scholars differ in opinion as to whether the story in this verse is merely a parable, with no basis in historical reality, or whether it is a true story.

Those who believe that this story is a true story differ as to who these two men were. According to a narration mentioned by Imam al-Qurthubi, some say that the two men were residents of Mecca from the tribe of Bani Makhzum. They were brothers, the believer named Yahuza and the disbeliever named Qurthus. Initially, they were together in a business venture, then they separated and divided their wealth. Each received thousands of dinars. Yahuza used one thousand dinars to free slaves, one thousand dinars to buy food for the displaced, and one thousand dinars to buy clothes for the hungry. As for Qurthus, he used his money to marry a wealthy woman and buy livestock, so that his wealth grew. The remaining money was used for trading and always brought profit, so that he became the richest man in his country at that time.

A narration mentions that this story is about a rich man with vast gardens and plantations. He owned two vineyards surrounded by palm trees, and between them was a field where various plants and fruits grew.
text.33: In this verse, Allah swt explains the condition of the two gardens that were full of fruits throughout the year. Their trees were always lush and dense. The two gardens never experienced decline or shortage throughout the seasons. They always yielded produce that brought prosperity to their owner. In the middle of the gardens flowed a river that could irrigate the land and fields around it at any time. Regular irrigation caused the plants to always be fertile, and the flowing river truly added to its beauty. That was a great pleasure that Allah had bestowed upon its owner.
text.34: Allah SWT explains in this verse that the owner of the garden still possessed other wealth in the form of trading assets such as gold, silver, and others, obtained from the sale of the garden and field produce. Qurthus truly lived a luxurious life, with abundant wealth, and possessed a large number of servants, laborers, and guards. This situation made him arrogant and ungrateful to the God who bestowed those blessings upon him. He said to his believing friend, who had previously called him to believe in Allah and the Day of Resurrection, "I have more wealth than you, as you witness, and more followers. They are ready at any time to defend myself and my family from my enemies, as well as to protect and defend my wealth." With these words, he implied that a person can live happily and prosperously without believing in the Lord of the Worlds. He assumed that all the glory he possessed and the pleasures he obtained were solely due to his own abilities. He did not feel that any God helped and provided sustenance and blessings to him.
text.35:
In this verse, Allah SWT explains that when he entered his garden with his brother, he said to his believing brother, while pointing to his garden, that these gardens would never perish.

There were two reasons that prompted him to say this:

First: Full confidence in the ability of human power to maintain the gardens, so that they would be safe from destruction. With wealth in the form of gold and silver as capital, and experienced and knowledgeable human resources regarding the care and maintenance of plants and gardens, he believed he was capable of maintaining the sustainability, beauty, and fertility of the garden and its plants. He was completely unaware of the limitations of human power and common sense and did not believe that there was a supernatural power capable of doing anything to all that wealth.

Second: Belief in the eternity of nature and time and disbelief in the Day of Judgment. He believed that everything that exists is eternal. Nothing will be destroyed from this universe; only changes and replacements occur according to the prevailing laws. Water, plants, soil, and others will continue to be available and will never cease.

Such was the view of the garden owner. Indeed, he had acted unjustly and dishonestly towards himself. He should have been grateful to Allah who had given him all the blessings. No one lives happily in this world by standing on his own feet alone, without the help or cooperation of others. Why did he boast, even though he was actually aware of it? Why did he deny God, even though he realized he was involved in the changes of nature itself? Why did he refuse to acknowledge who actually created all the changes in this universe and who created its laws? Why was he not honest with the recognition of his own conscience about the existence of God, the Most Creator? Indeed, such an attitude is a great injustice.
text.36:
This verse reveals the words of the garden owner to his believing brother regarding his disbelief that the Day of Judgment would come. If the Day of Judgment were to come and he were returned to God, he would certainly return to something better than the gardens he possessed in this world.

The attitude of the garden owner demonstrates a denial of the existence of the Day of Judgment (the Day of Resurrection). His assumption that he would obtain gardens better than his gardens in this world on the Day of Judgment was based on his experience that the two gardens he owned and entrusted to him by God continued to bear fruit and flourish only because of his ability and effort. Therefore, wherever and whenever, destruction always accompanies it. Allah SWT also describes the nature of this disbeliever in another verse with His words:

"…And if I am returned to my Lord, indeed, I will have with Him the best outcome…" (Fushshilat/41: 50)

The statements that lead to disbelief are: first, his acknowledgment of the eternity of nature; second, about the absence of the resurrection of humans from the grave; and third, his assumption that rewards in the afterlife are reflected by the state of the world. This view of the eternity of nature negates the decision and will of God, the Creator of the Universe. His denial of the resurrection of humans from the grave shows that he negates Allah's power to restore humans to their original form. The view that rewards in the afterlife are reflected by life in the world, for example, if someone in the world lives as a garden owner, then the reward in the afterlife is also for him as a garden owner. This is a primitive belief, or a belief based on culture. Such beliefs are contrary to religion that comes from the revelation of Allah SWT, who has wisdom in giving rewards to His servants.
text.37:
In this verse, Allah SWT explains Yahuza's response to refute his brother's thinking. Qurthus, the wealthy garden owner, looked down on Yahuza because of his poverty. Conversely, Yahuza looked down on Qurthus because of his disbelief (kufr). In his conversation with Qurthus, he stated that it was not fitting for him to deny the power of Allah who created him from the earth. Isn't the food that comes from plants or animals also from the earth? From that food and drink, cells are formed which eventually become *nuthfah* (a drop of fluid). *Nuthfah* develops stage by stage because it receives food, whether from vegetable or animal protein, until it becomes a man like Qurthus. How can someone deny the power of Allah, when his creation clearly demonstrates that power? Every human being is aware of himself, that in the beginning he did not exist, then he came into existence. It is impossible for his presence in this world to be connected by himself. The only Being who can connect that event is his Creator, namely Allah Rabbul Alamin (Lord of the Worlds).

To confirm the existence of the Day of Resurrection, Allah explains the process of human creation, as stated in His word:

"O mankind, if you are in doubt about the Resurrection, then indeed, We created you from dust, then from a sperm-drop..." (al-Hajj/22: 5)
text.38: In this verse, Allah swt explains Yahuza's statement to his disbelieving brother that he did not agree with him. He believed that there is no God worthy of worship except Allah, the Sustainer of creation, the One, and the Almighty. Yahuza also said that he did not associate partners with Allah in any way. His brother's stance that Allah was not able to resurrect him from the grave was completely unacceptable to Yahuza because it considered Allah weak and the same as creation. According to him, this was the same as shirk. Yahuza's firm attitude in the face of his wealthy brother was very commendable, even though he was in a state of poverty and in the position of someone asking for work, yet with full courage, he declared the difference in his personal identity (essence), namely a difference concerning the creed or faith in God.
text.39:
Yahuza then continued his words to Qurthus, "You should have given thanks to Allah when entering your gardens and felt amazed by their beauty. Why didn't you praise Allah for all the blessings He has bestowed upon you, in the form of abundant wealth and children that He has never given to others?"

"Say 'masya Allah' at that time, as a sign of acknowledging your weakness before Him, and that everything that exists could not have materialized without His permission and generosity. In His hands lies the fate of those gardens, fertilized according to His will or destroyed according to His will as well. Why didn't you say la quwwata illa billahi (there is no power except with the help of Allah) as a sign of acknowledging that there is no power that can prosper and manage it except with the help of Allah SWT." This verse contains a lesson about dhikr that is good to practice. Prophet Muhammad SAW said to his companion, Abu Hurairah:

"Shall I show you one of the treasures of Paradise located beneath the Arasy? I replied, "Yes, I want to." The Messenger said, "You recite la quwwata illa billahi." (Narrated by Imam Ahmad from Abu Hurairah)

Likewise, there are many hadith of the Messenger SAW that teach his ummah when receiving blessings from Allah to say that reading, Rasulullah SAW said:

"Every time Allah SWT gives a servant a blessing in family, wealth, or children, then he says "masya' Allah, la quwwata illa billah", of course Allah will protect him from all disasters until his death, then Rasulullah recited verse 39 of Surah al-Kahf." (Narrated by al-Baihaqi and Ibn Mardawaih from Anas r.a.)

After Yahuza finished advising his brother to believe, and had explained about the power of Allah SWT, he began to respond to his brother's words that boasted about his wealth and people. Yahuza said, "If you consider me poorer than you, both in terms of wealth and manpower, then it doesn't matter to me."
text.40: However, I hope that Allah will change my condition, grant me wealth, and bestow upon me a garden better than yours because of my faith in Him. Conversely, Allah SWT will eliminate the blessings He has given you because of your disbelief, and He will destroy your gardens by sending lightning from the sky that burns everything completely, so that it becomes a barren, slippery land.
text.41:
"Or Allah destroys those gardens with a calamity from the earth by drawing the water that flows through them and entering into the depths of the earth, so that you can do nothing to seek that water again."

Such was the hope of the believing Yahuza, that Allah would manifestly display His power to the disbelieving and arrogant man. With the descent of that punishment, whether in the form of a calamity from the sky or from the earth, the disbelieving man might become aware.
text.42:
In this verse, Allah SWT explains that what Yahuza hoped for would soon become a reality. Allah SWT then destroyed all the wealth of Qurthus. Previously, he had said with arrogance that his gardens would never perish. But after he witnessed the destruction of his wealth, deep sadness and regret arose, as he wrung his hands as a sign of regret for the loss of all the expenses he had spent on building his gardens all this time. All the plants and grapevines in the garden collapsed along with their supports. At the peak of his sadness, he remembered the advice and teachings of his brother, so he understood that the disaster came because of his polytheism and injustice towards himself. Then words of regret came out of his mouth, "Oh, if only I had believed and been grateful, surely the Lord would not have destroyed my gardens."

Such words of regret are born from a person who is already in great and unavoidable difficulty. Everyone, when cornered and in disaster, complains and words come out of their mouth that reflect their deep regret. Whereas if they are not cornered or not in misery, they will not utter such words.

Allah SWT says:

"Then when they saw Our punishment, they said, "We believe in Allah alone and disbelieve in that which we used to associate with Him." (al-Mu'min/40: 84)
text.43: In this verse, Allah swt explains that no group of people was able to help the owner of the garden, neither his family, guards, laborers, children, or anyone else who was previously his pride. Only Allah could help him from destruction and ruin. As for the man himself, he could not help himself with the strength he possessed.
text.44: Then Allah SWT affirms in this verse that in difficulties and tribulations such as those experienced by the owners of the garden, truly only Allah alone has the right and power to provide help. However, that help is only given to those who believe in Him, are grateful for His blessings, and are obedient and compliant to His commands. Allah will defend, reassure their hearts, and save them from all kinds of schemes and deceptions of their enemies. He is the best in giving rewards and recompense.
text.45:
Allah SWT likens the atmosphere of life in this world, along with all its beauty and splendor, which will gradually disappear, to the state of rainwater that is sent down from the sky, thus fertilizing the lush, flowering, and fruiting plants. The greenery gradually turns yellow and dry, and eventually disappears blown by the wind. Everything on this earth certainly goes through a process of change from birth, growth, development, withering, and disappearance. Therefore, humans who inhabit this earth should not be deceived by the magnificence of the world. Those who have great wealth should not boast about their wealth and should not belittle others who have no possessions. Indeed, wealth, sooner or later, will disappear. Allah, the Most Perfect and Most Glorious, who created all things and maintains them, grows them, destroys them, and then returns them to the earth. He is the Almighty and establishes the laws of change.

In the Al-Qur'an, many verses liken worldly life to the life of plants, including the word of Allah SWT:

"Know that the life of this world is but amusement and diversion and adornment and boasting to one another and competition in increase of wealth and children - like the example of a rain whose [resulting] plant growth pleases the tillers; then it dries and you see it turned yellow; then it becomes [scattered] debris. And in the Hereafter is severe punishment and forgiveness from Allah and approval. And what is the life of this world except the enjoyment of delusion." (al-Hadid/57: 20)
text.46:
Allah explains that what becomes the pride of humans in this world is wealth and children, because humans pay great attention to both. Abundant wealth and children can provide a respectable life and dignity to those who possess them. Like 'Uyainah, the wealthy Quraysh leader, or Qurthus, who held a noble position among his people, because they possessed great wealth and many followers. Because of wealth and children, people become arrogant and belittle others. Allah affirms that both are merely adornments of worldly life, not adornments and provisions for the hereafter. Yet, humans already realize that both will soon perish and are not worthy of being made a source of pride. In the order of this verse, wealth is mentioned before children, even though children are closer to the human heart, because wealth as an adornment is more complete than children. Wealth can help parents and children at all times, and with wealth, the continuity of the lineage can be guaranteed. Human need for wealth is greater than their need for children, but not the other way around.

Then Allah SWT explains that what is worthy of being boasted about is only good deeds whose fruits are felt by humans throughout time until the hereafter, such as acts of worship like prayer (salat), fasting (puasa), almsgiving (zakat), jihad in the path of Allah, as well as social acts of worship such as building schools, orphanages, homes for the elderly, and so on. These good deeds are better in reward in the sight of Allah than wealth and children who are far from the guidance of Allah SWT, and will certainly be defenders and intercessors for those who possess them on the Day of Judgment when wealth and children are no longer beneficial.
text.47:
In this verse, Allah swt explains various events that will occur on the Day of Judgment. These events include:

On that day, Allah swt will uproot the mountains from the earth's grip, causing them to crumble into dust and then be scattered into the air, just as Allah scatters the clouds. In another verse, Allah swt says:

"When the earth is shaken with a terrible shaking, and the mountains are crushed to powder, so they become scattered dust." (al-Waqi'ah/56: 4-6)

The surface of the earth at that time will appear barren. There will be no remnants of human civilization, trees, rivers, or seas that were previously on the earth's surface. All of humanity will be clearly visible before God, with nothing concealing their condition, as Allah explains in His word:

"And they ask you, [O Muhammad], about the mountains. Say, "My Lord will pulverize them and leave them as a level plain. You will not see therein a depression or an elevation." (Taha/20: 105-107)

On that day, Allah swt will gather all of humanity from the beginning to the end of time, after they have been resurrected from their graves. Not a single person will be left behind on that day to be examined, neither king nor commoner. This state of affairs is explained by Allah swt in His word:

"Say, "Indeed, the former and the latter will be gathered together for the appointment of a known Day." (al-Waqi'ah/56: 49-50)

The word of Allah swt:

"That is a Day when mankind will be gathered, and that is a Day [of judgment] to be witnessed." (Hud/11: 103)

The Prophet Muhammad saw also narrated the state of that terrible day as follows:

It is narrated from 'Aisyah ra that she said, "I heard the Messenger of Allah saw say, "On the Day of Judgment, people will be gathered (in the Gathering Place) barefoot, naked, and uncircumcised." I then asked, "O Messenger of Allah, will men and women see each other?" The Messenger saw replied, "O 'Aisyah, the matter of the Day of Judgment is more terrible than seeing one another." (Narrated by Muslim in his Sahih)
text.48:
In this verse, Allah SWT further explains what will happen on the Day of Judgment. The angels and humans will be presented before Allah in rows, saf demi saf (rows upon rows), like in congregational prayer, with each row distinct and not overlapping. Their atmosphere will be like soldiers before a king. Then, Allah declares to those who disbelieve and deny the Day of Judgment with a statement that shakes their hearts, that they are brought before their Lord without wealth or children, even without clothes or shoes, just as they were created the first time. As Allah explains in another verse with His words:

"And you have certainly come to Us alone as We created you the first time, and you have left behind you all that We bestowed upon you." (al-An'am/6: 94)

The Messenger of Allah SAW also explained about the events of the Day of Judgment with his saying:

"Indeed, Allah, the Most High, will call out on the Day of Judgment, 'O My servants! I am Allah, there is no god but Me, the Most Merciful of the merciful, the Wisest of the wise, and the quickest to take account. Prepare your excuses, make your answers easy. You will all be questioned and held accountable. O angels, arrange My servants standing in close rows for the reckoning.'" (Narrated by Ibn Mandah from Mu'adz bin Jabal)

Allah rebukes them because they used to think that the promised Day of Resurrection would not happen. In the past, they always boasted before the Muslims with their wealth and children while denying the Day of Judgment. But when the Day of Judgment arrives, they are powerless.
text.49:
In this verse, Allah swt adds information about the events that will occur on the Day of Judgment, namely that the book of records of a person's deeds during their life in the world will be given to them. The contents of the record are both good and bad, and some are given from the right side, while others are from the left. The believers and those who do good deeds receive it from the right side, and then they see its contents. It turns out that their good deeds are greater than their evil deeds, and the evil deeds are immediately forgiven by Allah swt. Then they are admitted into Paradise, as Allah swt says:

"Then as for him who is given his record in his right hand, he will say, "Here, read my record! Indeed, I was certain that I would be meeting my account." So he will be in a pleasant life, in an elevated Garden." (al-Haqqah/69: 19-22)

To the disbelievers and those who are guilty, the book of records of their deeds in the world is given from the left. Then they see its contents, and it turns out to be full of records of various evils, both in the form of actions and words. Such evidence causes fear in their hearts of Allah's punishment and the reproaches of people. With deep regret, they say, "Woe to us! What is this record that leaves nothing small or great but has accounted for it?" Their condition is further explained by Allah with His words:

"But as for him who is given his record in his left hand, he will say, "Oh, I wish I had not been given my record, and had not known what my account was! I wish it had been the decisive blow. My wealth has not availed me. My authority has departed from me." [Allah will say], "Seize him and shackle him. Then into Hellfire drive him." (al-Haqqah/69: 25-31)

They find all their actions that violate religious and humanitarian rules written before them. They forget that during their life in the world there were angels who always meticulously recorded all their actions and words. Allah swt says:

"And indeed, [appointed] over you are keepers - Noble and recording - They know whatever you do." (al-Infithar/82: 10-12)

All human actions are deliberately written in the book of records of deeds to be shown to them on the Day of Judgment. Allah swt says:

"(On the Day) when every soul will find present [before it] all the good it has done, and what it has done of evil..." (ali 'Imran/3: 30)

No one will be wronged on that Day of Judgment. Every deed will be weighed, no matter how small. Allah swt guarantees the establishment of justice on that day. His word:

"And We place the scales of justice for the Day of Resurrection, so no soul will be treated unjustly at all. And if there is [even] the weight of a mustard seed, We will bring it forth. And sufficient are We as accountant." (al-Anbiya'/21: 47)

Allah swt will not wrong His servants, on the contrary, He will grant forgiveness to those who are guilty, except for the sin of disbelief (kufr). He punishes them based on His wisdom and justice. Allah gives rewards to those who are obedient, and inflicts punishment on those who commit disobedience.
text.50:
In this verse, it is explained that when Allah commanded the angels to prostrate to Adam, they obeyed the command and prostrated to him. Only Iblis refused the command. Angels, who are always obedient to Allah, are among the unseen creatures, and no one knows their true nature. According to the explanation of the Al-Qur'an, angels are divided into several groups. Each group has its own tasks. In Islam, it is the angels who inspire humans to incline towards truth and goodness, as happened in the story of Maryam a.s. Meanwhile, it is the devil who tempts and creates doubts in the hearts of humans. He wants to encourage humans to do evil, as Allah swt says:

"Satan threatens you with poverty and orders you to commit immorality (stinginess)." (al-Baqarah/2: 268)

Angels and devils are spiritual beings that have a relationship with the human soul, but their true nature is unknown. Humans must believe as commanded in the pillars of faith without adding or subtracting from them. All humans can feel that if they intend to do something, there is a conflict in their soul between inclining towards good or evil, until one desire overcomes the other. If we incline towards good, it is the result of the encouragement of angels, and if we incline towards evil, then it is the encouragement of the devil.

From the point of view of their creation, both come from different elements. Angels were created from light, while jinn or devils were created from smokeless fire. Allah swt says:

"And He created the jinn from a smokeless flame of fire." (ar-Rahman/55: 15)

The Prophet Muhammad saw said:

"The angels were created from light, Iblis was created from smokeless fire, and Adam was created as has been narrated to you." (Narrated by Muslim from 'A'ishah r.a.)

Iblis refused to prostrate to Adam because, according to him, the element of fire is higher than earth. Because Adam was made from the element of earth, Iblis felt humiliated if he was ordered to prostrate and pay respect to him, as Allah tells in His word:

"(Allah) said, "What prevented you from prostrating when I commanded you?" (Iblis) said, "I am better than him. You created me from fire, while him You created from clay." (al-A'raf/7: 12)

Iblis's opinion is very wrong because the height of degree and glory does not depend on origin, but on obedience to Allah. Because he did not want to prostrate to Adam, Iblis became a transgressor in the sense of not obeying God's command. Iblis refused to obey because the content of Allah's command was contrary to his way of thinking. So, he objected to prostrating to Adam. Iblis has a talent for being rebellious and always resisting according to the basis of his creation from smokeless fire.

After explaining the transgression of Iblis, God reminds humans not to place Iblis and his descendants as leaders, because they are enemies of humans and enemies of God. Many narrations, both from the Prophet Muhammad saw and from the companions, show that Iblis and his descendants (devils) continue to multiply, and mankind is reminded not to be tempted by their seduction to follow them.

Devils are scattered on the face of the earth to tempt humans. Only the unjust humans submit to the temptation of devils and make them leaders and protectors. Indeed, devils are the worst of Allah's creatures. People who follow devils are said to be unjust because Allah swt, who has sent down mercy and blessings to them, is abandoned, and they prefer the invitation of devils.
text.51:
In this verse, Allah SWT explains His power and declares that Satan has no right to be a guide or protector for humans. Satan has no right as a protector, not only because he was created from a flame of fire, but also because they have no share in creating the heavens and the earth. Allah SWT affirms that Iblis and the devils were not present to witness the creation of the heavens and the earth when Allah created them, nor even the creation of themselves, nor did some of them witness the creation of others. If they had no part in that creation, how could they possibly provide assistance in that creation? Thus, is it fitting that the devils be made partners with Allah? Allah SWT, in creating the heavens and the earth, never made the devils, idols, and other objects of worship as helpers at all. Only Allah created the universe, without the help of anyone. Therefore, the devils and idols are not worthy of being made partners with Allah in the worship of His servants. Because, that which is worshipped is only that which participated in creating the earth and the heavens. Partners in creation, partners also in receiving worship. And conversely, not partners in creation, not partners also in receiving worship. Therefore, only Allah SWT has the right to receive worship.

Allah SWT says:

"Say, "Invoke those you claim [as deities] besides Allah." They do not possess an atom's weight [of ability] in the heavens or on the earth, and they have therein no partnership [with Him], nor is there among them any assistant to Him." (Saba/34: 22)
text.52:
In this verse, Allah reminds the Messenger of Allah about the Day of Judgment. Allah calls out to the polytheists with His call, "Try calling upon those whom you glorified in the world, and whom you considered as partners to Me. Perhaps they are able to provide protection and intercession for you, and then release you from the torment you are facing at this moment." Then they immediately call upon those deities to ask for help and to intercede for them. However, it turns out that those deities cannot do anything at all to help them, not even answer the call. Allah places between those disbelievers and their deities, a place of destruction (maubiq/hellfire). *Maubiq* in this verse can also mean enmity, meaning that enmity occurs between those deities and their worshippers, as in the word of Allah SWT:

"And they have taken gods besides Allah, that they might be for them [a source of] strength." No! Those [gods] will deny their worship of them and will be against them adversaries. (Maryam/19: 81-82)
text.53: In this verse, Allah SWT explains that the sinful people, namely the idol worshippers or those who worship other than Allah, will witness the fire of Hell on the Day of Judgement. They will realize that they will enter that Hell, and there will be no way out of that threat at all. Allah has decreed punishment for them. There is no possibility for them to avoid the punishment, because they are surrounded from all directions. How great will be their sorrow as they await the punishment that is inflicted upon them.
text.54:
This verse explains that Allah presents various kinds of parables in the Qur'an, whether in the form of comparisons to something or in the form of stories. This is intended as a mirror of comparison for humans, because they possess intellect. From small animals, such as mosquitoes, ants, flies, and bees, to large natural objects, such as mountains and oceans, are used as examples to attract human attention. Nevertheless, humans are the creatures most prone to arguing. This means that when Allah awakens their intellect and noble character with various parables, they seek excuses to deny and refuse to obey. This is due to the influence of desires, arrogance, and the deception of Satan and Iblis.

In a hadith it is narrated that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) came to Ali and Fatimah one night and asked:

"Have you two prayed?" So I (Ali) replied, "O Messenger of Allah, our souls are indeed in the hands of Allah, if He wills to awaken us, He is certainly able to awaken us." So he turned away when I said that, and he did not answer my words at all. Then I heard him strike his own thigh while turning away and saying, "But man is the most argumentative of creatures." (Narrated by al-Bukhari from Ali bin Abu thalib)
text.55:
After many kinds of parables and comparative analogies have been presented in the Qur'an, but it turns out that many people disbelieve, Allah returns to give an explanation about the arrogance of the disbelievers in the past. They denied the messengers and refused to follow the guidance they brought. Even though they had witnessed for themselves clear signs and proofs about the truth of that guidance, they still did not repent and still refused to follow it. Whereas if they wanted to follow the guidance of the messengers and abandon polytheism, ask forgiveness from Allah, and repent for the disobedience they had committed in the past, they would surely be forgiven. But they did not do any of that.

Likewise, the polytheists of Quraysh, they did not want to follow the guidance of the Qur'an, because of the nature of disbelief and stubbornness that had taken root in their souls. This nature is what prompted them to ask that punishment be inflicted upon them, as had been inflicted upon those who came before, namely a punishment that destroyed them to their roots (azab istishal), or a punishment that was inflicted upon them successively, punishment after punishment, manifestly.

The request of the polytheists of Quraysh who opposed Allah and mocked the Messenger of Allah (saw) is explained by Allah (swt) in His word:

"And (remember) when they (the polytheists) said, "O Allah, if this (the Qur'an) is indeed the truth from You, then rain down upon us stones from the sky or bring us a painful punishment." (al-Anfal/8: 32)

Their attitude like that shows excessive disbelief that is detrimental to themselves.
text.56:
In this verse, Allah explains the task of His messengers, which is to convey guidance and make people aware of their duties in two ways:

First: through *tabsyir*, which is conveying glad tidings. Whoever follows and obeys Allah's guidance, He will surely grant them salvation in this world and the hereafter.

Second: through *indzar*, which is conveying news containing threats. Whoever refuses to obey Allah's guidance, but follows Satan and their own desires, will suffer loss and misfortune, both in this world and in the hereafter.

The guidance brought by the messengers is absolute truth because it comes from Allah. Whoever denies it, as the disbelievers do, means they are denying absolute truth. In other words, the disbelievers are making an absolute mistake. Moreover, the path they take is the wrong path. They do not take the straight path, meaning they are on a crooked path. They oppose sanctity, meaning they are taking a dirty path. Their desire to eradicate the truth will only be in vain. Because the truth will remain standing firm.

This is what every messenger always experiences in carrying out their task of conveying the truth and Allah's guidance. The messengers face challenges and resistance from arrogant people. The call to truth and Allah's warnings are only the subject of their ridicule and mockery. In fact, it is not uncommon that when the disbelievers are cornered and overwhelmed, they issue threats directly aimed at the messengers or their followers.
text.57:
In this verse, Allah explains that rejecting the truth is a great injustice. Allah has warned in a pleasing manner, in the form of good news, or in the form of threats, but the disbelievers and the polytheists remain stubborn, and continue to choose disbelief and the acts of disobedience they continue to commit.

With this stubbornness and rejection of the truth, it means they have oppressed or wronged themselves. The injustice they commit against themselves invites Allah's punishment that comes in succession upon them. After they reject the truth brought by the messenger, they also forget their acts of disbelief and disobedience. Their rejection of the truth causes them to be dragged into acts of disobedience.

These mistakes cause them to forget the blessings that Allah has given them. Finally, they are completely unable to think about the consequences that will befall themselves. Their hearts have hardened, so they cannot understand any truth. They no longer hear the call of the truth of Islamic Sharia, and they get worse day by day, so that no medicine given will be able to help. This verse is very appropriately applied to the polytheists of Mecca who died in disbelief.
text.58:
In this verse, Allah SWT explains that He is the Most Forgiving, and His mercy is vast, encompassing the entire universe, everything in the heavens and on earth. One proof of Allah's generosity and vast mercy is that He does not immediately inflict punishment upon the disbelieving polytheists. This is intended to give them an opportunity to regain consciousness, because every human being has a seed of goodness within them. It is hoped that their clear minds will nurture their human nature to develop and remember God. So that if they want to ask for forgiveness, even if their sins are piled up and mountainous, they will surely be forgiven by Allah, the Most Generous and Most Compassionate. Indeed, there are some among those who are astray who can free themselves from error, and then return to the right path.

Although Allah possesses the attribute of restraining His wrath, is Most Forgiving, and His Mercy is Vast, if the grace period that has been given is not used to realize themselves, then the time that Allah has promised to punish the polytheists and disbelievers will come. When that deadline arrives, they must be held accountable for all their deeds. They must bear Allah's punishment as a result of their own actions. At that time, no one can defend them, and there is no place that can be used as refuge.
text.59:
In this verse, Allah reminds us of the lands that were destroyed along with their inhabitants, because they persisted in wrongdoing and disbelief in Allah's verses, even though they had been given warnings and threats by the messengers sent to them.
