These lands and their inhabitants include: Madyan (the land of the people of Shu'aib), al-Hijr (the land of the people of Thamud), al-Ahqaf (the land of the people of 'Ad), and Sodom (the land of the people of Luth).

Their destruction is deliberately mentioned again with the intention that, even though Allah possesses the attributes of the Forgiving and the Vast in Mercy, if a nation or the inhabitants of a land persist in wrongdoing and disbelief in Allah's verses, they will be destroyed along with their land.

In addition to the aforementioned attributes, Allah also possesses the attribute of the Most Just. He will inflict torment and punishment in accordance with the actions of His servants themselves. This also applies to the disbelieving and polytheistic Quraysh. When the time comes, the leaders of the Quraysh of Mecca will be destroyed by God, as happened in the Battle of Badr.

This warning is also intended to strengthen and solidify the faith of those who already believe.
text.60:
In this verse, Allah recounts the tenacity of Prophet Musa (peace be upon him)'s determination to reach the meeting point of the two seas. No matter how many years the journey would take, it was not a problem for him, as long as that place was found and what he sought was obtained.

The reason Prophet Musa (peace be upon him) was so determined to find that place was because he received a reprimand and command from Allah, as narrated in a hadith which, among other things, reads as follows:

"Verily, Musa (peace be upon him) (one day) gave a sermon before the Children of Israel. Then a man asked him, "Who is the most knowledgeable person?" He replied, "I am." Then Allah reprimanded him because he did not attribute that knowledge to Allah Taala. Then Allah revealed to him, "I have a servant at the meeting point of the two seas who is more knowledgeable than you." (Narrated by al-Bukhari from Ubay bin Ka'ab)

In that revelation, Allah commanded Prophet Musa to meet that person, bringing a fish in a kampil (basket), and wherever the fish escaped and disappeared, that is where that person would be found. Then Musa (peace be upon him) went to meet the person mentioned, and the hadith does not explain where the place was. Such was the determination possessed by a person whose heart was close to his Lord. With agility and enthusiasm, he carried out His call.

Most scholars are of the opinion that the Musa referred to in this verse is Prophet Musa bin Imran, the prophet of the Children of Israel to whom Allah revealed the Torah, which contains the Sharia. Prophet Musa was a prophet who possessed various extraordinary miracles. Their reasons include that the Musa mentioned in the Qur'an is the Musa who received the Torah. Thus, the Musa here must also be the Musa who received the Torah. If the Musa meant in this verse was another Musa, there would certainly be an explanation.

According to Nauf al-Bukali, the Musa meant here is Musa bin Misya bin Yusuf bin Yakub, a prophet who was appointed before Prophet Musa bin Imran. Their reasons include:

1. It is illogical that the Musa meant here is Prophet Musa bin Imran. Because he was a prophet who had spoken directly with Allah, received the Torah from Him, and was able to defeat his enemies with extraordinary miracles. How can it be accepted logically that someone as extraordinary as that would be told by Allah to go and meet another person and still have to learn from him.

2. Musa bin Imran, the prophet of the Children of Israel, after leaving Egypt and going to the Sinai Desert, never left that place and he died there.

These reasons can be refuted. No matter how high a person's knowledge is, there will certainly still be weaknesses. Similarly, with Prophet Musa, there must be shortcomings and weaknesses. It is in this aspect that Khidr was superior to Prophet Musa. This is what Prophet Musa had to learn from him, namely the things that Allah SWT told in the following verses.

Prophet Musa's departure from the Sinai Peninsula may not have been announced to the Children of Israel, so they assumed his departure was to commune with Allah. After returning, Prophet Musa did not tell about his meeting with Khidr because that event may not have been understood by his people. Therefore, the young man who accompanied him was instructed to keep it a secret.

The young man who accompanied Prophet Musa was named Yusya bin Nun bin Afratim bin Yusuf (peace be upon him). He was his assistant and student. It was Yusya who led the Children of Israel into Palestine when Prophet Musa had died.

In this verse, Allah has given an example of politeness according to Islamic teachings, namely to call one's servant or domestic helper with the term fata (young man) for male servants, and fatat for female servants. Prophet Muhammad (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) once said:

"Let none of you call my male slave or my female slave, but let him call fataya or fatati." (Narrated by al-Bukhari and Muslim from Abu Hurairah)

Regarding the person whom Prophet Musa (peace be upon him) was going to meet, it was Balya bin Malkan. Most commentators call him Khidr. They also believe that he was a prophet, based on Allah SWT's words:

"...whom We had granted mercy from Ourselves and whom We had taught knowledge from Ourselves." Musa said to him, "May I follow you so that you may teach me from what you have been taught of sound judgment?" (al-Kahf/18: 65-66)

What is meant by mercy in this verse is the revelation of prophethood. Because the continuation (end) of this verse mentions that the mercy was directly taught from Allah without an intermediary, and only the prophets are entitled to receive such a thing. Moreover, in the following verse, it is mentioned that (Prophet) Khidr should teach true knowledge to Prophet Musa. No prophet learns from a non-prophet. Furthermore, in verse 82 it is also mentioned:

"And I did it not of my own accord." (al-Kahf/18: 82)

The meaning of the verse above is that after Prophet Musa and Yusya followed him, Prophet Khidr did strange and illogical things. But when Prophet Musa asked him, that was his answer. This means that Prophet Khidr's actions were based on revelation from Allah, and this is strong evidence for his prophethood.

From the descriptions above, it can be concluded and learned that humility has a value that is far better than arrogance.
text.61:
In this verse, Allah recounts that after Prophet Musa (Moses) and Joshua reached the meeting point of the two seas, they stopped, but they did not know that this was the place they were supposed to go. This is because Allah did not specifically tell them the exact location. Allah only provided guidance when asked by Prophet Musa before they departed, as in the words of the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) when narrating Prophet Musa's question:

"O my Lord, how can I find him?" Allah said, "Take a fish and put it in a basket. When the fish is lost, that is the place." (Narrated by al-Bukhari from Ubay bin Ka'ab)

On a large rock at that place, Prophet Musa and his disciple felt sleepy and tired. They both fell asleep and forgot about the fish. At that time, the fish in the basket came back to life and thrashed around, then went out and slid towards the sea. Even though the basket was in Joshua's hand at that time. This event, namely a dead fish coming back to life, is a miracle for Prophet Musa (peace be upon him).

After waking up, they continued their journey. Joshua forgot to tell Prophet Musa about the strange incident of the dead fish coming back to life.
text.62:
In this verse, Allah recounts that the two of them continued their journey day and night. Prophet Musa (Moses), feeling hungry, said to his disciple, "Bring us our food; indeed, we have suffered fatigue from this journey."

The feeling of hunger and fatigue after passing the meeting place of the two seas turned out to contain wisdom, namely, to restore Prophet Musa's (peace be upon him) memory of the fish they were carrying.

In this verse, Allah reveals how noble Musa's (peace be upon him) character was in his attitude towards his disciple. What his disciple carried as provisions was shared property, not just his own. How refined his feelings were when he realized that fatigue and hunger were not only felt by him, but also by others.
text.63: In this verse, Joshua answered honestly that when they rested and took shelter at the rock where the two seas met, the fish had come back to life and wriggled, then entered the sea in a very astonishing way. However, he forgot and did not tell Prophet Musa a.s.. This oversight was not because he was irresponsible, but because Satan caused it.
text.64: Hearing such an answer, Prophet Musa welcomed it with joy, saying, "That is the place we were looking for. In that place, we will meet the person we are seeking, namely Prophet Khidr." They then returned, following their original tracks, to find the rock they had used as shelter. According to al-Biqa'i, Allah's word in this verse indicates that they were walking in the desert, so there were no signs, but there were their tracks. So, it is possible that what is meant in Allah's word about the meeting of the two seas is the meeting of fresh water (the Nile River) with salt water (the Mediterranean Sea), namely the city of Dimyath or Rashid in the land of Egypt.
text.65:
In this verse, it is narrated that after Prophet Musa and Joshua retraced the path they had taken earlier, they arrived at the rock that had been used as a resting place. At this place, they met a person covered in a clean white cloth. This person is called Khidr, while his real name is Balya bin Mulkan. He was given the title Khidr because he sat in a white place, while behind him there were green plants. This explanation is based on the following hadith:

It is narrated from Abu Hurairah that the Prophet saw said, "He was named Khidr because he sat on a white animal skin. When that place moved, green plants appeared behind it." (Narrated by al-Bukhari)

In this verse, Allah swt also mentions that Khidr is a person who received knowledge directly from Allah. That knowledge was not given to Prophet Musa, just as Allah had bestowed knowledge upon Prophet Musa that was not given to Khidr.

According to Hujjatul Islam al-Ghazali, broadly speaking, there are two ways for a person to gain knowledge:

1. The process of teaching from humans, called *at-ta'lim al-insani*, which is further divided into two, namely:

a. Learning from others (outside oneself).

b. Learning independently using the ability of the mind.

2. Teaching that is directly given by Allah to someone, called *at-ta'lim ar-rabbani*, which is also divided into two, namely:

a. Given by way of revelation, whose knowledge is called: *'ilm al-anbiya'* (the knowledge of the prophets) and this is exclusive to the prophets.

b. Given by way of inspiration, whose knowledge is called *'ilm ladunni* (knowledge from the side of God). *'Ilm ladunni* is obtained directly from God without intermediaries. The event can be likened to a ray from a hidden lamp that directly strikes a pure, clean, empty, and gentle heart. This inspiration is an adornment given by Allah to His beloved ones (the *wali*).
text.66:
In this verse, Allah states the intention of Prophet Musa (peace be upon him) in meeting Khidr, which was to learn from him. Prophet Musa greeted Khidr and said to him, "I am Musa." Khidr asked, "Musa from the Children of Israel?" Musa replied, "Yes, that is correct!" Then Khidr paid his respects to him, saying, "What is your purpose in coming here?" Prophet Musa replied that he had come to him so that he would be permitted to follow him, with the intention that Khidr would teach him some of the knowledge that Allah had taught him, namely beneficial knowledge and righteous deeds.

In this verse, Allah clearly depicts the attitude of Prophet Musa as a prospective student to his prospective teacher by making a request in the form of a question. This means that Prophet Musa was very careful to maintain politeness and humility. He placed himself as an ignorant person and asked to be allowed to follow him, so that Khidr would be willing to teach him some of the knowledge that had been given to him. According to al-Qadhi, such an attitude should indeed be possessed by every student in asking questions to their teacher.
text.67:
In this verse, Khidr answers Prophet Musa's question as follows, "O Musa, you will not be able to have patience with me. Because I possess knowledge that Allah has taught me which you do not know, and you possess knowledge that Allah has taught you which I do not know."

Khidr's ability to foresee Prophet Musa's attitude if he were to accompany him was based on the *ilmu ladunni* that he had received from Allah in addition to the knowledge of the prophets (*ilmu anbiya'*) that he possessed, as mentioned in verse 65 above. And indeed, such was the nature and attitude of Prophet Musa, who was firm in facing realities that contradicted the *sharia* that he had received from Allah.
text.68:
In this verse, Khidr affirms to Prophet Musa (Moses) the reason why he will not be patient if he continues to accompany him. There, Prophet Musa will see the reality that Khidr's actions outwardly contradict the sharia of Prophet Musa (peace be upon him). Therefore, Khidr said to Prophet Musa, "How can you be patient with actions that outwardly violate your sharia, when you are a prophet? Or perhaps you will also find my actions outwardly reprehensible (mungkar), while in reality you do not know their purpose or benefit."

Indeed, that is the nature of a person who is not patient with reprehensible (mungkar) actions that he sees. He will even immediately deny them.
text.69: In this verse, Prophet Musa promised not to deny or contradict what Khidr did. He also promised to carry out Khidr's orders as long as those orders did not contradict the commands of Allah. The promise he made in this verse was based on the words "insya Allah" because he was aware that patience is a very great and weighty matter, especially when witnessing wrongdoing.
text.70:
In this verse, Khidr was able to receive Moses (peace be upon him) with the message, "If you (Prophet Moses) walk with me (Khidr), then do not ask me about anything I do and about its secret, until I myself explain the matter to you. Do not rebuke me for an action that you cannot justify until I myself begin to mention it to explain the true situation."

Prophet Moses agreed to that condition. Indeed, Prophet Moses' attitude was the proper etiquette of a learned person towards a scholar, the proper etiquette of a student with his teacher, or the attitude of a follower with the one he follows. Sometimes the secret of a teacher or the one being followed is not necessarily understood by the student or follower at that moment, but can only be understood later on.
text.71:
In this verse, Allah recounts that the two of them (Prophet Musa and Khidr) had walked along the seashore to look for a ship, and then found one. The two of them then boarded the ship without paying the fare, because the crew already knew Khidr and the fare exemption was as a tribute to him.

When the ship was sailing in the deep sea, Khidr suddenly took an ax and pierced and damaged a piece of board in the ship's wall. Seeing such an event, Prophet Musa immediately said to Khidr, "Why did you pierce the boat? This could drown all the innocent passengers? Indeed, you have caused great damage and are ungrateful for the kindness of the crew who have exempted us from the ship's fare." Then Prophet Musa took his cloth to cover the hole.
text.72: In this verse, Khidr reminds Prophet Musa of the conditions he must fulfill if he still wishes to accompany Khidr on the journey. Khidr also reminds him that Prophet Musa will not be able to be patient with the actions he performs, and that he will even oppose them and call those actions a great mistake, because Prophet Musa does not have the knowledge to know the secrets contained behind those actions. Khidr said to Prophet Musa, "Did I not say that you would never be able to have patience with me?"
text.73: In this verse, Prophet Musa realized and acknowledged his forgetfulness regarding his promise. Therefore, he asked Khidr not to punish him for his forgetfulness, nor to burden him with work that was difficult to do. Prophet Musa also asked Khidr to be given another opportunity to follow him so that he could gain knowledge from him, and to forgive his mistake.
text.74:
In this verse, Allah recounts that both of them landed safely and did not drown. Then, they disembarked from the ship and continued their journey along the coast. Khidr then saw a child playing with his friends and killed him. Some say that Khidr killed him by beheading him, others say by strangling him. However, the Qur'an does not mention how Khidr killed the child, whether by beheading him, smashing his head against a stone wall, or in another way. We do not need to pay attention to or investigate this.

Seeing this event, Prophet Musa immediately said to Khidr, "Why did you kill a soul pure of sin, and not because he killed another? Indeed, you have done something abominable, which is contrary to sound reason."

In this verse, the killing is referred to with the word *nukr* (abominable), while the damaging of the boat in verse 71 is referred to with the word *imr* (a grave error). The reason is that the killing of the child is more heinous than damaging the boat. Damaging the boat does not take a life if it does not sink. But killing or taking a life that is not in line with religious teachings is clearly an abominable act. Killing that can be justified by religious teachings is only for apostasy, *zina muhsan*, or for *qishash*.
text.75: In this verse, it is explained how Khidr rebuked Musa's question, saying to Musa (peace be upon him), "Did I not say to you that indeed you would not be able to have patience to learn the knowledge of the reality with me?" Indeed, Musa had twice objected and disagreed with Khidr's actions, even though Musa had promised not to raise any objections to what Prophet Khidr did. Khidr's warning to Musa was the final warning.
text.76:
Then Moses said, "If I ask you again about any of your strange actions that I have witnessed, because I want to know the wisdom behind them, not just to ask for the sake of asking, then do not allow me to accompany you anymore, for you have already given me enough excuses." These were Moses' words, full of regret for his actions, which he was forced to acknowledge and realize.

It is narrated in an authentic hadith that the Prophet Muhammad (peace and blessings be upon him) said about the state of Prophet Moses as follows:

May Allah have mercy on us and on Moses. If he had been patient with his companion (Khidr), he would have witnessed many wonders of the knowledge of reality, but because he felt ashamed to face further reproach from his companion (Khidr), he said, "If I ask you about anything after this, then do not accompany me. Indeed, you have already given me enough excuses." (Narrated by Muslim from Ubay bin Ka'ab)
text.77: Then Moses and Khidr continued their journey until they reached a certain town. They asked the people of the town to host them, but the people of the town were very stingy and unwilling to offer them hospitality. Their morals were very low, because according to the customs of that time, if a wealthy person refused to give alms to a beggar, it was greatly condemned, and if he refused to host a guest, it showed a very low moral decline. In this regard, the Arabs expressed their very harsh condemnation with the words: "So-and-so refused a guest (expelled him) from his house." Qatadah said, "The worst of towns is the one whose inhabitants do not like to receive guests and do not want to acknowledge the rights of Ibn Sabil (a traveler who has run out of provisions)." In that town, Moses and Khidr found a house wall that was about to collapse, so Khidr repaired it with his own hands, so that the wall stood upright again. This strangeness was one of his miracles. Moses, seeing the wall being erected again by Khidr without taking any wages, wanted to suggest to Khidr that he accept payment for his service in erecting the wall, with which payment he could buy food and drink that he desperately needed.
text.78:
This verse explains Khidr's answer to Moses, "This third question of yours is the cause of the separation between me and you." Some Quranic commentators (Ulama Tafsir) say that the reason for the separation did not occur with the first and second questions, because the first and second questions concerned reprehensible acts (munkar), namely killing an innocent child and making a hole (damaging) in the ship's wall, so it was reasonable to forgive them. As for the third question, Khidr was doing good to a miserly people who did not want to offer him hospitality, and that act was a good deed that did not need to be refuted or questioned.

Khidr said, "I will inform you of the various wisdoms behind my actions, which you could not be patient with, namely killing the child, making a hole in the ship, and erecting the wall of the house. The purpose was to save the ship from confiscation by a tyrant, to save the parents of the murdered child from disbelief if he lived, and to replace him with a righteous sibling, and to save the inherited wealth belonging to the two orphaned children who were under the wall that was about to collapse."
text.79:
Khidr explained the reasons for the various actions he had taken. As for Khidr's act of making a hole in the boat, it was because the boat belonged to a weak and poor people. They were unable to resist the tyranny of the king who would seize their boat, and they used the boat to increase their income by transporting merchandise or renting it to other people. Khidr deliberately made a defect in the boat by making a hole in it because in front of him was a tyrannical king who liked to seize and confiscate every intact boat and would not take a defective boat, so that because of the defect, the boat would be saved.

Prophets usually determine something according to the realities that appear before them, while matters that are internal secrets are left to the wisdom of Allah in accordance with the wording of a hadith quoted from the book Tafsir al-Maragi, Volume VI, page 7, as follows:

"We (the Prophets) determine something according to the facts that appear in sight, while Allah knows the truth."

The laws that apply in this world are based on the essential causes, namely the actual facts, and this is only shown by Allah to some of His servants. Therefore, Prophet Musa denied Khidr's actions and he did not know that Khidr had been given *ilmu laduni* (divinely inspired knowledge) that could know the secrets of unseen matters. The rank of Prophet Musa is in the field of *sharia* (Islamic law) and laws based on the real world, while Khidr was given knowledge of *ilmu hakekat* (knowledge of reality) so that he knows the secrets of unseen matters. In the first and second questions of Prophet Musa, there is an application of a principle in the science of *usul fiqih* (principles of Islamic jurisprudence) which means that if two harms occur that cannot be avoided, then take the lighter harm to avoid the greater harm. If the boat's wall was not holed, it would certainly be confiscated by the king of a tyrannical country that would pass through it.
text.80:
As for the child who was killed, he was a disbelieving child, while his parents were truly believers. So we feared that because of their love for the child, they would both be drawn to disbelief. Qatadah said, "His parents were happy when the child was born, and they were saddened when he was killed." And if he had lived, he would have caused hardship and destruction for his parents. Therefore, everyone should accept Allah's decree with joy, because Allah's decree for a believer in something he dislikes is better than Allah's decree for him in things he likes. It is mentioned in a hadith that the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said:

"Allah does not decree for a believer a decree, except that there is good in it for him." (Narrated by Ahmad and Abu Ya'la)

This is also in accordance with Allah's saying:

"Fighting has been enjoined upon you while it is hateful to you. But perhaps you hate a thing and it is good for you; and perhaps you love a thing and it is bad for you. And Allah Knows, while you know not." (al-Baqarah/2: 216)

Khidr said, "We knew that if the child grew up, he would invite his parents to disbelief, and they would both follow his invitation because of their great love for their child."
text.81: This verse explains that Khidr hoped that Allah would provide sustenance to the two parents and a son who was better than the child who had been killed, and who would have more affection for his parents. Khidr's act of killing the child was based on the desire that in time, Allah could replace that child with one who was better in character.
text.82:
As for what motivated Khidr to erect the wall, it was because beneath it lay a treasure belonging to two orphaned boys in that city, and their father was a righteous man. Allah commanded Khidr to erect the wall, because if the wall were to fall (collapse), the treasure would become visible and there was fear it would be stolen. Allah willed that the two orphans reach adulthood and extract their treasure themselves from beneath the wall, as a mercy from Him. Khidr did not perform all these actions out of his own motivation and will, but solely upon the command of Allah, because any action that results in damage to people's property and bloodshed is not permissible except with the permission and revelation from Allah. Such was Khidr's explanation regarding his unusual actions that caused Prophet Musa to be unable to be patient, leading him to question them.

Khidr's effort to erect the nearly collapsing wall can also be understood as wisdom, because the collapse of the wall would result in the treasure of the two orphans being taken by others. Allah had given Khidr the knowledge of *haqiqat* (inner truth), and this is impossible for him to possess except after purifying himself and his heart from the bonds of physical desires. Prophet Musa, when his knowledge of *sharia* (Islamic law) was complete, was sent by God to meet Khidr in order to learn from him the knowledge of *haqiqat*, so that the knowledge that is obligatory for every believer to seek would be complete, namely the knowledge of *tawhid* (Islamic monotheism), *fiqh* (Islamic jurisprudence), and *tasawuf* (Islamic mysticism) or *iman* (faith), *Islam* (submission), and *ihsan* (excellence).
text.83: The Quraysh asked Muhammad after they had first consulted with the Jews about what they should ask Muhammad to test the truth of his prophethood. They asked Muhammad about Dhul-Qarnayn, so Allah instructed Muhammad to declare to them, "I will recite to you complete stories about what you asked because I have been given information by my Lord." Then he gave the details as explained in the following verse:
text.84: Indeed, God had given power to Dhul-Qarnayn to explore this universe as he wished, so that he reached all corners of the world and controlled the kingdoms of the earth. And God had given him the means to achieve all his intentions and goals because God had given him sufficient knowledge, vast power, and the equipment needed to achieve that goal.
text.85: This verse explains that Dhul-Qarnayn took a path towards the West. After he traveled that path, he reached the westernmost edge of the earth where the sun appeared to set as if entering the Atlantic Ocean. There, he saw the sun setting in a sea that appeared dark and muddy. He had passed through the lands of Tunisia and Morocco and reached the western coast of Africa, and there he encountered some disbelieving people. Allah commanded him to choose between two things: to punish them with bloodshed or to invite them to believe in Allah. This is explained in Allah's word conveyed to Dhul-Qarnayn through inspiration (ilham). Dhul-Qarnayn was instructed to kill them if they refused to acknowledge the Oneness of Allah and refused to submit to his invitation, or to teach them guidance so that they would know the laws and precepts of religion with full conviction.
text.86: This verse explains that Dhul-Qarnayn took a path towards the West. After he traveled that path, he reached the westernmost edge of the earth where the sun appeared to set as if entering the Atlantic Ocean. There, he saw the sun setting in a sea that appeared dark and muddy. He had passed through the lands of Tunisia and Morocco and arrived at the western coast of Africa, and there he encountered some disbelieving people. Allah commanded him to choose between two things: either to punish them with bloodshed or to invite them to believe in Allah. This is explained in Allah's word conveyed to Dhul-Qarnayn through inspiration ( *ilham*). Dhul-Qarnayn was instructed to kill them if they refused to acknowledge the Oneness of Allah and refused to submit to his invitation, or to teach them guidance so that they would know the laws and precepts of religion with full conviction.
text.87: Dhul-Qarnayn said to some of the commanders of his army, "As for those who wrong themselves and continuously live in associating partners with Allah (shirk), then we will punish them, and then in the Hereafter they will be returned to their Lord to be punished with an unparalleled punishment in Hell (Jahannam)."
text.88: As for those who affirm Allah and His Oneness and perform righteous deeds, then for them is prepared the best reward as recompense for all the good deeds they performed during their life in this world. And We will command them in the world with commands that are easy to perform, namely, actions that can draw them closer to Allah, such as prayer (salat), alms-giving (zakat), striving in the way of Allah (jihad), and so on.
text.89: As for those who affirm Allah and His Oneness and perform righteous deeds, then for them is prepared the best reward as recompense for all the good deeds they performed during their life in this world. And We will command them in the world with commands that are easy to perform, namely, deeds that can draw them closer to Allah, such as prayer (salat), alms-giving (zakat), jihad, and so on.
text.90: The verse explains that Dhul-Qarnayn took a path towards the East. After he reached the west coast of Africa, he then returned towards the east until he arrived at the rising place of the sun, around the land of China, where he encountered a group of people whose lives were not under the shelter of houses, nor were there trees to shade them from the heat of the sun. They were directly exposed to the sunlight because they were not protected by roofs or hills in their surroundings. During the day, they stayed in holes underground and only emerged above the surface of the earth after sunset to seek their livelihood. Their condition was very different from the inhabitants of the rest of the world, because their lives were still primitive and they had no buildings for shelter.
text.91: Furthermore, the journey of Dhul-Qarnayn, as has been explained above, led him to the western and eastern extremities, and he reached the peak of his greatness in his reign, which was rarely matched. Indeed, We knew everything that was with him and everything that he did with his armies, even though they were widely dispersed across the entire surface of the earth.
text.92: Then he took another path, namely a path between the Mashriq (east) and Maghrib (west), turning towards the north. That is, towards the two mountains in Armenia and Azerbaijan.
text.93: When he reached a place between two mountains located behind the Jihun River in the land of Balkh near the city of Tirmidh, he encountered a group of people who barely understood the speech of their own companions, let alone other languages. This was because their language was very different from the languages known to humankind, and their level of intelligence was also very low.
text.94: Through their spokesperson, they said, "O Dhul-Qarnayn, indeed Gog and Magog, suspected by some researchers to be the Tartar and Mongol nations, are causing great corruption on earth through murder, plunder, and all kinds of violence. So, be prepared to accept a reward from us, which we will collect from our possessions, so that you may build a barrier for us to protect us from their attacks."
text.95: Dhul-Qarnayn answered, "What Allah has bestowed upon me, namely knowledge, sufficient understanding, a great kingdom, vast power, and abundant wealth, is better than the wages you offer me. Therefore, we express our gratitude for all your kindness, and I only require the assistance of manpower and tools so that I can build a barrier between you and them."
text.96: "Bring me pieces of iron." And after they brought the pieces of iron, then Dhul-Qarnayn arranged and installed the iron pieces until its height was level with the two mountain peaks. Then he said to his workers, "Operate the bellows to ignite the fire and heat the iron." So that when the iron had become red like fire, he said again, "Now bring me molten copper to pour over the hot iron," so that the holes were sealed tightly and a strong and sturdy iron fortress was formed.
text.97: And when Gog and Magog launched an assault on that place, they were unable to climb it due to its extraordinary height, and they were also unable to pierce it because it was so hard and thick.
text.98:
Then Dhul-Qarnayn said, "This barrier is a mercy from my Lord to His servants, therefore it is a strong fortress that protects them from the attack of Gog and Magog. But when the promise of my Lord comes about their emergence from behind the barrier, then He will make it crumble into dust, level with the ground because Allah gives power to a people to destroy it, and the promise of my Lord is true, without doubt."

According to historians, Dhul-Qarnayn's statement was proven by the case of the emergence of King Genghis Khan who caused destruction on earth from East to West and launched attacks that destroyed the iron fortress and the Islamic kingdom in Baghdad. The reason King Genghis Khan launched an attack on the land of Baghdad was because Sultan Khuwarazmi of the Seljuk dynasty had killed several envoys and merchants sent from his country. Their property was plundered and attacks were also carried out on the borders of his country, which aroused the anger of King Genghis Khan. Then he wrote a letter to the Sultan of Baghdad with harsh words as follows, "Why did you dare to kill my friends and plunder my trade goods? Are you awakening a sleeping lion and causing hidden evils?"

Did not your Prophet give you a testament not to commit injustice? Therefore, leave the Turkish people alone as long as they do not disturb you. Why do you hurt your neighbors when your Prophet himself has bequeathed to respect neighbors? And this is my testament to you, "Take good care and consider your wisdom before the rise of revenge and before the opening of the iron fortress. And Allah will surely help every oppressed person, therefore wait for the arrival of Gog and Magog who will descend from every high place."

"From Umm Habibah ra from Zainab bint Jahsh ra, that the Messenger of Allah (saw) one day entered the house of his wife, Siti Zaenab bint Jahsh and with surprise he said, "La ilaha illallah, woe to the Arabs from an evil that has approached, today a large hole has been opened in the Fortress of Gog and Magog like this." And he circled his thumb with his index finger. Then Zaenab asked, "O Messenger of Allah, will we be destroyed even though there are many righteous people among us?" He replied, "Yes, when evil is abundant." (Narrated by al-Bukhari)

Since that day, the hole in the fortress has become increasingly large. In the 7th century Hijri, the army of King Genghis Khan came to attack and caused various damages on earth, especially in the land of Baghdad.
text.99:
On the day the iron fortress crumbles, Gog and Magog will emerge from behind the fortress in waves, destroying crops and property, as mentioned in Allah's word:

"Until when Gog and Magog are let loose [from their barrier], and they descend from every elevation." (al-Anbiya'/21: 96)

On the day the wall is opened, We will leave them to surge upon one another in a chaotic state. Then, that situation will remind the inhabitants of the earth when the trumpet is blown by the angel Israfil on the Day of Judgment, and they will be gathered in the Plain of Assembly (Mahsyar) to be judged. In accordance with Allah's word:

Say, "Indeed, the former and the latter peoples will be gathered at the appointed time of a known Day." (al-Waqi'ah/56: 49-50)

And Allah's word:

And [mention, O Muhammad], the Day We will remove the mountains and you will see the earth prominent, and We will gather them and not leave behind from them anyone. (al-Kahf/18: 47)
text.100:
And We will present Hell on that Day, when the trumpet is blown, to the disbelievers, displaying its immense horror and ferocity, and they will hear its sounds and terrifying flames, so that they will be certain that they will soon be plunged into it and will not be able to escape from it.

It is narrated by Abu Sa'id al-Khudri that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said:

"How can I be happy when the angel Israfil has already brought his mouth close to the end of the trumpet and has lowered his forehead and his ears are ready to hear when the command comes from Allah to blow the trumpet. And if the pilgrims gathered in Mina were to lift that trumpet from the earth together, they would not be able to (because of its great weight)." Then the companions of the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) fell silent and felt burdened upon hearing that news. Then the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said, "Say (enough is) Allah as our savior, and He is the best helper. Only in Allah (do we put our trust)." (Narrated by Ahmad and at-Tirmidhi)
text.101: This verse explains that a painful punishment is prepared for those whose hearts are always closed to observing the signs of Allah's greatness in this world. They never contemplate the proofs of His power, never repent to their Lord, never follow His commands and avoid His prohibitions, as if they close their ears, refusing to hear the warnings from Allah. Such punishment is inflicted upon them as a consequence of their involvement (wallowing) in sin and transgression, following the temptations of Satan, entering the traps set by Satan, so that their hearts are locked shut by God, making them unable to use their eyes and ears to receive guidance and truth. And Allah explains that whatever they worship besides Allah cannot benefit them in the slightest.
text.102: Do the disbelievers who associate partners with Me think that My servants who are within My power, such as the angels, Jesus son of Mary, and the idols they worship, can they take them as helpers to save themselves from My wrath and punishment? Their assumption is completely misguided and wrong, and Allah firmly declares again, "Indeed, We have prepared Hell for the disbelievers as a dwelling place and as a recompense for what they offer to their objects of worship."
text.103: This verse explains Allah's command to the Prophet Muhammad to say to those who dispute with him among the People of the Book, namely the Jews and Christians, "Shall I inform you of those who are the greatest losers in their deeds, those who have toiled hard doing a deed, hoping for reward and favor through that deed, but what they obtain is only disaster and destruction, like those who have bought goods hoping for profit, but what they obtain is only loss."
text.104: That is, those whose efforts are wasted in accumulating good deeds in the world, they perform actions that contradict those pleasing to Allah, and they think that they have done the best of deeds. Then it turns out that they have erred and taken a misguided path, so that the good deeds they have done are of no benefit whatsoever, like dust that is blown away by the wind.
text.105: Those whose efforts are in vain are those who disbelieve in the verses of their Lord and disbelieve in the Day of Resurrection, even though on that Day they will be brought before the Day of Meeting with Allah. Therefore, all their deeds will be nullified, so that there will be no good deeds to be weighed on their scales. For what will weigh heavily on the scales on the Day of Judgment are only righteous deeds that are free from shirk.
text.106: That recompense is a consequence of their disbelief in Allah's messengers and the miracles they brought, which they always made a mockery of. They not only disbelieved but also mocked and humiliated Allah's messengers, which also meant humiliating Allah who sent them.
text.107:
Indeed, those who believe in Allah and His Messenger, and affirm the message of the Messengers, and perform righteous deeds solely to attain His pleasure, for them is prepared the Garden of Paradise (Firdaus) as a dwelling place. It is narrated by al-Bukhari and Muslim from Abu Hurairah (may Allah be pleased with him), that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) said:

"When you ask Allah, ask Him for Paradise (Firdaus), for it is the most excellent and highest Paradise, and above it is the Throne of Ar-Rahman (the Most Merciful), and from Paradise (Firdaus) flow the rivers of Paradise." (Narrated by al-Bukhari and Muslim from Abu Hurairah)
text.108: They will abide therein forever and will not desire removal therefrom, because there is no place more noble and more magnificent in their sight except the Gardens of Paradise (Jannah Firdaus).
text.109:
It is narrated that the Jews said to the Prophet Muhammad, "You say that we have been given wisdom by Allah, while in your book (Al-Qur'an) there is a verse:

And whoever is given al-hikmah (wisdom) is indeed given abundant good. (al-Baqarah/2: 269)

Then you also say, as mentioned in the Al-Qur'an:

And you have not been given of knowledge except a little. (al-Isra/17: 85)

They believed there was a contradiction between these two verses, so this verse was revealed as an answer to their criticism. The Messenger was commanded to say to them, "Say, 'If the sea were ink for [writing] the words of my Lord, the sea would be exhausted before the words of my Lord were exhausted, even if We brought the like of it as a supplement,' because the sea is limited while the knowledge and wisdom of Allah are unlimited."

Like the word of Allah:

"And if whatever trees upon the earth were pens and the sea [was ink], replenished thereafter by seven [more] seas, they would not exhaust the words of Allah. Indeed, Allah is Exalted in Might, Wise." (Luqman/31: 27)
text.110:
Say to them, "Indeed, I am only a man like you, acknowledging that all my knowledge is not comparable to the knowledge of Allah. I only know what Allah has revealed to me, and I do not know anything else except what Allah has taught me. Allah has revealed to me that, "What is worshipped by me and by you is only the One God, who has no partners." Therefore, whoever hopes for reward from Allah on the Day of Meeting with Him, then let him be sincere in his worship, affirming the Oneness of Allah in His Rububiyah and Uluhiyah and not associating partners with Him, whether openly or secretly, such as riya, because doing something with the motive of wanting to be praised by people is considered hidden shirk. After purifying faith from shirk, one should always perform righteous deeds that are done solely to achieve His pleasure.

Narrated by Muslim from Abu Hurairah (ra), that the Messenger of Allah (saw) said:

Indeed, Allah says, "I am the most independent of all partners from their partnership. And whoever performs an action associating others with Me, then I will leave him with his partner." (Narrated by Muslim from Abu Hurairah)
